information:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 1-2 weeks. The April 2025 Eurozone inflation data is typically released by Eurostat in early May, so the outcome should be known by mid-May 2025 at the latest.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: No - the question will resolve as No. The most recent inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, and the consensus forecast from economists is 2.1% for April 2025, which would be below the 2.2% threshold.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Inflation continues its recent downward trajectory from 2.3% (February) to 2.2% (March) to 2.1% or below in April. This decline is driven by continued disinflationary pressures including weak economic growth (PMI below 50 for ten consecutive months), decelerating wage pressures, easing food inflation, and negative contributions from energy prices. The ECB's seven interest rate cuts further dampen demand and price pressures.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Inflation remains at 2.2% or ticks above this level despite the downward trend. This could occur if services inflation proves stickier than expected (services contributed +1.56pp in March), if there's an unexpected uptick in food or energy prices, or if seasonal factors temporarily push the rate higher. Measurement variations or rounding effects could also result in a reading marginally above 2.2%.
forecast.rationale: The evidence strongly points toward a No outcome. The inflation trend is clearly downward: 2.3% in February declining to 2.2% in March. The consensus forecast from Bloomberg and Reuters polls is 2.1% for April, below the 2.2% threshold required for a Yes resolution. Multiple disinflationary factors are at work: the ECB has implemented seven rate cuts bringing the deposit rate to 2.25%, the composite PMI has been at or below 50 for ten consecutive months indicating weak economic activity, wage growth is decelerating from late 2024 peaks which should reduce services inflation pressure, and energy prices are contributing negatively to inflation. The status quo outcome - that the world changes slowly and trends tend to persist - strongly favors continuation of the downward inflation trajectory. However, I don't assign an extremely low probability to a Yes outcome because: (1) the March reading was exactly at 2.2%, so we're very close to the threshold, (2) consensus forecasts have typical errors of 0.1-0.2 percentage points, (3) services inflation remains elevated at +1.56pp contribution, and (4) there could be unexpected shocks or seasonal factors. For me to update significantly higher toward Yes, I would need to see evidence of services inflation remaining stickier than expected, unexpected commodity price increases, or stronger-than-expected economic data. For me to update lower toward more confident No, I would need to see consensus forecasts moving to 2.0% or below, clearer signs of services disinflation, or weaker economic indicators. Given the clear downward trend, supportive economic fundamentals, and below-threshold consensus forecast, but acknowledging forecast uncertainty and the proximity of March's reading to the threshold, I estimate the probability at 23%.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the Euro Area Inflation Rate be above 2.2% for April 2025?

Question background:
Euro News: [Euro falls as eurozone inflation sees downward revisions in February](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/03/19/euro-falls-as-eurozone-inflation-sees-downward-revisions-in-february)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the Eurozone inflation rate for April 2025 is above 2.2% on an annualized basis according to [Trading Economics](https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi).




Your research assistant's report says:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

Today is 2025-04-28.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
